Team Fortress 2 is old but its gameplay remains a masterclass in class-based design: every character feels distinct, expressive, and mechanically satisfying, and the balance between chaotic action and strategic depth is still unmatched. Few shooters manage to blend personality, humor, and competitive intensity the way TF2 does.

But what truly elevates TF2 is its community. The game has long outgrown its status as ‚Äújust a shooter‚Äù and has become a creative ecosystem of its own. Countless talented animators have taken the game‚Äôs iconic characters and turned them into high-quality animations, short films, and even creative taunts. Some of these community creations reach a surprisingly high level of quality, making TF2 feel alive far beyond the matches themselves (I‚Äôm thinking of The Winglet‚Äôs videos).

Another unique charm of TF2 is its social atmosphere. It‚Äôs one of the few multiplayer shooters where, if you want, you can try being friendly with your own enemies; whether it‚Äôs dancing with a Spy, taunting beside a Pyro, or forming spontaneous ‚Äúpeace zones‚Äù mid-match. These small moments of camaraderie and absurdity are part of what makes TF2 timeless: it‚Äôs not just a game, but a shared playground where anything can happen if you want it to.

Even today, TF2 stands as an exceptional title: rich in character and sustained by one of the most passionate communities in gaming. It remains a true classic that continues to thrive, evolve, and inspire.

Honestly, I have to wonder what the hype was like in the leadup to Team Fortress 2's release back in 2007. Imagine being a fan of the original Quake mod and Team Fortress Classic, anticipating the release of the new game, and then it releasing on the same day as Portal and Half-Life 2: Episode Two, aw it must have been glorious.

Anyways, Team Fortress 2, always been a great game, you just never get enough of the crazy mercenaries we all know and love. Plus, having the nine different classes gives the game a lot of replayability. If you've grown tired of playing the same class all the time, you've got 8 other dudes to wake that tire. Plus the game is chock full of different game modes to duke it out in.

But sometimes the game can match you up with people way above your level. There's nothing more frustrating than going into a game, and getting killed by the same person over, and over, and over. (That's probably why domination was implemented.) So I'd like to give a mention to Mann vs. Machine, which is basically you as a team of six taking on a huge horde of AI-controller enemies. It can be a nice breather from PvP, if you just want to feel awesome and kill a ton of enemies.

And huge shoutout to the community servers, because TF2 is known for having a ton of community-made content, like FreakFortress, or LazyPurple's servers that are either a silly friendly server with silly maps that you don't fight each other in, or a CRAZY 20-player MvM server, which I find myself hopping into every now and then. And some community-made maps are really well-made, shoutout to Ethosaur and his maps like the Ennui Box, and Lethargy Pools.

If there's ONE thing I wish the game did have though, it's a campaign mode, that delves into the background story of Team Fortress, such as what's seen in the comics. I doubt we'll ever get that, but it's something I've always wanted.

But if there's one thing I just CANNOT stand about the game, it's players who go "Valve, give us more updates!" "What 8 years of no updates does to a man." Um, guys, I think this game has enough content in it to be considered a complete game. And also, there are entire maps and entire game modes in this game that ZERO people play. If you want something new, why don't you give Mannpower and Pass Time a try if you want new content so bad. And again, community servers, always buzzing with community-made content.

Oh and regarding the bot epidemic that happened a while back, I'm glad it's fixed, but keep in mind Valve took almost 5 years to fix it, that doesn't exactly make them saints...

You can play this game without paying a single dime, it costs absolutely nothing to download and play normally without voice chat, text chat, anything like that. All you have to do is buy any one item in TF2, some costing as little as a dollar, and you'll gain access to voice chat and be able to communicate with other players. I'd encourage any players who want to get good at the game to either buy some weapons they want to try out or grind the achievements and unlock a few weapons that way. The main thing about TF2 is that there are multiple ways you can play. What I mean is that there are 9 characters, or "classes" you can play as. I recommend trying them all out and seeing which ones you like playing the best. Me personally, I think that the Engineer, Spy, and Soldier are my three favorite classes to play. However, other players might like to play other classes like Scout, Demoman, Medic, or Heavy. It all really depends on YOUR playstyle what classes suit you best, So here's what I recommend to people just looking at this game and reading the reviews before downloading: Spend some time (preferably equal amounts) on each class and find out what playstyle you like best. There are stock weapons for each class, but I'd recommend trying out some weapons in the shop (There's a free trial option for those who aren't sure about a weapon they want to try that gives a 25% discount on them during the trial that you can do once a week) to try to optimize your playstyle. My default spy loadout, for example, has the "Deadringer" watch, the "Your Eternal Reward" knife, and the "L'etranger" pistol because they work so well together when going behind enemy lines and killing off the enemy team wile staying hidden.

TLDR: Try everything. Throw shit at the wall and see what sticks. Learn your playstyle. Once you do what you love, you'll love what you do. That's what makes TF2 so fun in the end.

First, this game suffers widespread neglect from the Devs. Now that's not a big deal by itself, but up until about a year ago this game was plagued by Spinbots that made public games unplayable.
Second, getting new items is painful. The game is fun! but certain characters such as Pyro and Medic feel like they need unlocks to be at their most interesting or fun. So how do you do that? simple, go achievement hunting or wait for a long ass time until a random item is dropped at your feet. if you already have that item, tough shit.
Third, lack of tutorials or guides makes finding information a pain sometimes. Jump Maps are nice and all, but the fact that you'd need a third party add-on to make the learning process less hellish is certainly something. This game has a lot of interesting tech for each class, but finding it, let alone practicing, can be a pain.

They finally got rid of the bots at some point... but recently, they've been back again.

The only way to play properly is going on community servers, and there aren't many of those since new players aren't getting funneled to them, instead they have to deal with Valve's crappy casual matchmaking and presumably quit the game because the experience there is shit even when there's no cheating bots.

Yes the game is old but Valve is still adding new cosmetics and profiting from it, the least they could do is make it playable without having to jump through hoops. Last Halloween update broke matchmaking... each update something breaks, this is just unacceptable and sad really.
